Comment: The Four Knights Opening (C47, I think), which a lot of players consider boring. Indeed it's not an opening I'd ever play with White, even in Blitz.

The textbook moves are Bb5, d4 and the interesting g3!? 
This 4.d3? move was first played by Blackburne back in 1896 and he actually went on to win the game - a rare feat for white in this opening. 
4.d3? was popular in a tournament in Dubai in 1986, with black winning nearly every game. 
As far as I can find it has NEVER been played by a GM.
Mark Hebden played as black against 4.d3? in 1987 and went on to win.
Bc5 is also possible.
Now we are completely out of the Database (Bg5 and exd5 are the Database moves), which was perhaps my opponent's orginal intention in playing 4.d3?
8. ... f5! I'll allow myself a little exclamation mark for this move. It's more aggressive (the key in blitz games) than other options such as Bd6 or Bc5.

9.exf5?
A poor move, allowing development of my Queen's bishop 'for free'. 
Much better for white was 9.c3! fxe4 10.Ng5
0-0-0 always leads to an attacking game with both forces aiming to sack the king's position.

12.b4 looks better as it gains much needed space for white.
Another good possibility is 12.Bg5.
You can't play perfect chess and here h6 (preventing Ng5) or the aggressive e4 might have been better.
Ng5 is better.

A pointless move.
14.Rad1 Be4 15.Rxd6 cxd6 was better for white.

A pointless move.
14.Rad1 Be4 15.Rxd6 cxd6 was better for white.

?
It is a well-known fact in chess: bad moves always come in pairs.
15.Bh4 e4 16.Bxc6 Rxc6 is much better for white.
16. ... bxc6? would be a poor reply for black as 17.Be7 Re8 18.Bxd6 cxd6 19.Nd4 gives white the advantage.

?
It is a well-known fact in chess: bad moves always come in pairs.
15.Bh4 e4 16.Bxc6 Rxc6 is much better for white.
16. ... bxc6? would be a poor reply for black as 17.Be7 Re8 18.Bxd6 cxd6 19.Nd4 gives white the advantage.

Not so good is 15. ... Rxc6?! 16.Be3 Bd6 17.Rfe1.
And certainly not 15. ... bxc6? 16.Be7 Rf7 17.Bxd6 cxd6 18.b4 with advantage to white.

Better for white is 16.b4 Bb6.
Two bad replies from black would be: 
a) 16. ... bxc6 17.bxc5 Rd5 18.Rfe1; and 
b) 16. ... Rxc6 17.bxc5 Rxc5 18.Rfe1 -
both allow white to equalise.

Better for white is:
17.Rfe1 e4 18.b4 Bb6 (not 18. ... exf3 which allows white to equalise after 19.bxc5 Rdd8 20.Re5).

Better for white is:
17.Rfe1 e4 18.b4 Bb6 (not 18. ... exf3 which allows white to equalise after 19.bxc5 Rdd8 20.Re5).

g4! :) Oh yes, you have to like this intuitive move!
It sacrifices the e-pawn and the potentially powerful push 17. ... e4.
If 17. ... e4 18.Nxg5? Bxf2  19.Kh1 e3 and it's game over.
However after 17. ... e4 18.Nd4! Bxd4 19.cxd4 Rxd4 20.Bc2 Rfd8 21.Bxd3 exd3 Black goes into the rook & pawn endgame clearly better but hardly a clear win. These endgames are notoriously 'drawish'.

If 18.b4 Bxf2 ! 19.Kxf2 gxf3 20.g3 e4
and Black has 2 connected passed pawns and a won position.
Be2! is much better than the over-anxious Bxf2 .
This allows Black to keep his bishop on the dangerous line pinning White's f2 pawn to his king.
